Bill Callahan ''Woke on a Whaleheart'' (Drag City)

A few years ago the Italian-Icelandic singer Emiliana Torrini recorded an exquisite song called ''Honeymoon Child.'' Accompanied by nothing besides a flickering guitar she murmured, ''You are a true honeymoon child, conceived on an island in the sun/Heels dug in the white sand, loved and adored by everyone.''

Listeners who read the credits might have noticed that the song was written by Bill Callahan, the indie-rock singer-songwriter who records as Smog. Or used to. His new album, ''Woke on a Whaleheart,'' is the first one released under his own name. It includes his own version of ''Honeymoon Child,'' which tugs the story in a different direction. Where Ms. Torrini sounded affectionate, Mr. Callahan sounds as if he's reserving judgment for a while, or forever. He has perfected a singing-talking hybrid that can make him sound like a (nearly) dispassionate narrator. Near the end of ''Honeymoon Child,'' there's an ominous but mysterious twist: ''Mr. Bones from town said he saw you the other day/Said you'd changed but he wouldn't say how.'' That can't be good news. Can it?

In the years since his 1990 debut album, ''Sewn to the Sky,'' Mr. Callahan has ruthlessly revised and edited his approach, discarding much of the noise -- lo-fi distortion, extra instruments -- so that listeners can (or have to) concentrate on those obstinate chord progressions and that obstinate voice.

Still, by Mr. Callahan's standards, ''Woke on a Whaleheart'' is an exuberant album; it includes a skewed gospel song (''The Wheel'') and an unexpectedly forthright, if long-winded, love song (''From the Rivers to the Ocean''). ''Day'' seems to be a bitter (if vague) protest song, but the stern opening line -- ''Some people are a sickness on this land'' -- soon gives way to a playful instruction: ''Learn from the animals/Monkeys do, monkeys do, monkeys do piggish things too.''

There are times when Mr. Callahan's deliberate, word-centric approach seems merely perverse instead of brave, and somehow the album seems much shorter than its 40 minutes, as if it's only a sketch for what's next. So: what's next?
